raw_text:
Benitez joy as Reds take control
 
 Liverpool boss Rafael Benitez was satisfied after his team's 3-1 win over Bayer Leverkusen despite conceding a goal in the last minute.
 
 "Before the game if you had said the score will be 3-1 I would have happily accepted that," said Benitez. "But you must realise that you have to concentrate right to the very last seconds of a game at this level. "I have confidence that we can complete the task in Germany. I am always confident and we must be positive."
 
 Benitez defended goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek, whose failure to hold on to Dimitar Berbatov's weak drive allowed Franca to score with the last kick of the game - and give the German team a lifeline for the second leg. "For me it was not Jerzy Dudek's fault," added Benitez. "He had played a very good game - and had we scored our other chances, nobody would be talking about about their goal. It would not have mattered. "If we had scored our other chances it would not have been worth remembering that last goal. "In my opinion Jerzy played well, made two very fine saves - and I am happy with him. "If we lose 2-0 we are out but I think we can score in Germany - certainly one, and that will make all the difference." And the Liverpool boss is looking forward to having skipper Steven Gerrard, who was suspended for the Anfield leg, back for the return in Germany.
 
 "Steven Gerrard is a key player for us," said Benitez. "When he is on the pitch he makes everyone else play better - and the opposition pay special attention to him - which gives space for others. "Steven is one of the best players in the world, but I need a team that is not about just one player. There must be 11 players on the pitch all doing well."
llama3.2:1b: Liverpool's 3-1 win over Bayer Leverkusen was marred by Jerzy Dudek's failure to hold off Dimitar Berbatov's weak drive, allowing Franca to score with the last kick and giving Germany a lifeline for the second leg.
Benitez defended his goalkeeper but also praised Dudek's performance, saying "it would not have mattered" if they had scored their other chances.
He is confident that Liverpool can still win in Germany despite the loss.
llama3.2:3b: Rafael Benitez was satisfied with Liverpool's 3-1 win over Bayer Leverkusen despite conceding a last-minute goal.
He defended goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek, saying his performance was good and that the team could still achieve their goal in Germany.
Benitez also expressed confidence in Steven Gerrard returning from suspension, calling him "one of the best players in the world" but emphasizing the importance of teamwork.

He praised goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek for his performance, stating that it wasn’t a decisive goal and Liverpool could still score in Germany to advance to the next round.
Benitez is also looking forward to Steven Gerrard returning for the second leg of the tie in Germany.

He emphasized the importance of concentrating right to the very last seconds, as he had confidence that they can complete the task in Germany.
For Liverpool, it is crucial for them to secure victory against Bayer Leverkusen and keep Steven Gerrard on their team.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Liverpool coach Rafael Benitez praises his team's victory over Bayer Leverkusen and emphasizes confidence going into the return match in Germany despite conceding in extra time.
Benitez defends goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek but acknowledges failure to prevent Franca's goal, stating they can still score in Germany if one additional point is sufficient.

Benitez also expresses optimism about returning key player Steven Gerrard, noting that his presence improves team performance and focuses opponents' attention on multiple players rather than just one star player.

He defended goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek for allowing Franca to score, stating that missing other chances would have overshadowed this goal.
Benitez emphasized his confidence in scoring at home and looking forward to Steven Gerrard returning for the return leg.

opencoder:1.5b:
Summarized text:

Redefining football's charm: Benitez is now the Reds' newest contender, taking control of Liverpool's Bayer Leverkusen.
Following his win over Germany, he was happy to complete a 3-1 win in time despite conceding a goal in the last minute.
"Before the game if you had said the score will be 3-1, I would have happily accepted that," Benitez assured.
But, you must realise that it is an all-or-nothing task.
To ensure accuracy, you have to focus on the very last second of each game.
Fueled by confidence and a vision: Benitez insists he has a confidence build to complete the task in Germany.
He always finds himself confident when it comes to scoring goals - and this could give the team a lifeline for the second leg after the first.
Joy as Reds decide to take over: "For me it was not Jerzy Dudek's fault," Benitez explained.
He had played an exceptional game, with the goalkeeper making everyone else play better and the opposition focusing on him - which gives space for other players.
"When he is on the pitch, he makes everyone else play better, and the opposition pay special attention to him."
Looking forward: Benitez said his boss looks forward to Steven Gerrard, who was suspended for the Anfield leg, back for Germany.
"Steven Gerrard is a key player for us," Benitez said.
"When he is on the pitch, he makes everyone else play better - and the opposition pay special attention to him."
smollm:1.7b: Benitez was satisfied after his team's 3-1 win over Bayer Leverkusen despite conceding a goal in the last minute.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Benitez was content after scoring a 3-1 win against Bayer Leverkusen despite conceding a goal.
He praised the importance of concentration during the last few minutes in high-stakes matches.
Benitez highlighted his confidence in completing the task in Germany and expressed pride in his team's ability to defend.
He acknowledged the strong performance of goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek, who held on tightly to Dimitar Berbatov's weak drive.
Benitez also stressed the importance of a cohesive unit, with Steven Gerrard available for future matches at Anfield.
tinyllama:1.1b: Benitez is satisfied with Liverpool's 3-1 win over Bayer Leverkusen despite conceding a goal in the last minute, citing the team's ability to overcome defeat and having a positive mindset for the upcoming fixture against Borussia Dortmund.
He also defended goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek's performance, stating that it was not his fault, and praised Liverpool forward Steven Gerard as an essential player who makes others play better.
Benitez is looking forward to having him back in the team for the return leg in Germany, citing Gerard's impact on previous meetings between the two sides as a reason.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Liverpool boss Rafael Benitez is pleased with his team's performance in their 3-1 win over Bayer Leverkusen and believes they can improve for the second leg against the German team.
However, he remains confident that Liverpool will complete the task in Germany.
During the match, Liverpool failed to hold on to a crucial lead as Dimitar Berbatov's effort was denied by goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek.
The missed shot allowed Franca to score with their only shot of the game, putting the team's progress into jeopardy.
Speaking after the game, Benitez addressed the last goal from German team defender Franca: "I think it was not Jerzy Dudek's fault.
He had played a very good game and had us scored our other chances, there would have been no reason to worry."
The manager is looking forward to having his captain, Steven Gerrard, back for the second leg match in Germany.
Benitez praised his team's discipline and determination during the match, stating they will continue working hard to achieve their goal of completing the task in Germany.
The Liverpool boss emphasized that they must be positive and continue to improve for the upcoming game against the German team.

Despite this setback, Benitez remains confident in completing a successful result in Germany.
